Description: Hollow terracotta figure of Harpokrates standing, wearing a long tunic and a bound wreath surmounted by lotus buds; the ends of the ribbon of its binding fall onto his shoulders; a Double Crown rises between the buds. He has a full head of hair, his finger to his mouth, and holds a two-handled pot with vertical ribbing in his left hand. He leans his right elbow on an amphora in a stand. At his left is a horned altar on top of which is a large circular loaf or cake stamped with a central rosette. Flat-faced plinth. Back plain; oval vent. Fragment broken from the face of the plinth. Two-piece mould. Orange-brown Nile silt with some mica. Traces of black paint here and there.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Said to be from Saqqara. Ptolemaic, probably third to second century BC. Comparanda: Close: Allen 1985: no. 55, from Karanis, dated first century BC/AD. Near: Tsujimura 1999: 16, fig. 12:1, from a Ptolemaic context at Akoris. Bibliog: Budge 1925: pl. xxviii.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3049)
Condition: good but piece lost from the plinth
